ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Combination of recorded lecture and live virtual lecture
A combination of live and recorded
Live virtual lecture with discussion breakout rooms in class.
Combo: live/pre-recorded virtual
Recorded lecture one day a week, then live lecture plus discussion groups the other day.
N/A
Both recorded lecture and one in-person lecture.
Two recorded lectures, one discussion

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned about techniques and methods archaeologists used to investigate sites. Learned how to read archaeological papers and seeing how this research is used to contribute to the history we know about ancient civilizations
I learned a decent amount about archaeology in this class. We learned about archaeological methods as well as reading about the archaeology of many ancient civilizations.
Solid foundations in archaeology and ancient civilizations from across the globe.

An overview of ancient civilizations, and an intro to many aspects of archaeology-- technology for surveying sites, interpreting different data (ex how to gain info from bones, stones tools, etc), theories about development of societies, etc.
I learned a lot about ancient civilizations around the world - how they came to be, how they functioned, and how they grew and developed over time.
I became more conscious of the biases present in retellings of history and the knowledge we have of the past.

This course was a great entry into the world of contemporary archaeology. Professor Wolin gave not only insights into past civilizations, but also a look into how these insights were made, though her methods lectures.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I liked the format of the recorded lectures and live sessions, I thought it brought a good balance during the semester.

One of the strengths of the class was the variation between the different weeks. Each week we addressed a different civilization, and it was nice to see a wide array of sites. Classes weren't very engaging because there were lots of long silences and not many people were willing to talk, though I think this is partly the fault of the students more than the course. Homework assignments that asked us to engage in different ways, other than just discussion posts, might have been useful in sparking discussion in class.

Strengths-- usually very interesting content, very nice and invested instructor, very reasonable time expectations. Weaknesses-- frankly, the other students sometimes. It would be awkward sitting in silent zooms or having to have the prof ask many times for people to turn on their cameras. This sometimes attracts people who just do not want to engage, through no fault of the professor.
lectures contained discussion sections where we broke off into smaller groups and went over questions, which was helpful
Strengths include the breakout discussions. Room for improvement would be hands on material, but unfortunately this is a constraint of COVID.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I honestly liked the format of the class and don't have any complaints. I think the professor was very understanding of how the pandemic is affecting all of us and she always communicated her priorities very well. The assignments were pretty fun, including the discussion posts, extra credit assignments, and midterm.

I think this class definitely suffered by being changed to virtual format. Normally, we would visit the Peabody and other museums and be doing hands on activities to learn archaeological methods. But this semester we were restricted to just doing readings and watching recorded, which were not particularly engaging. In-class zoom polls or other in-class interactive activities would have made the class more interesting in the virtual format. I also think if the class met twice a week instead of once, it might have been more engaging.
The recorded lectures and weekly discussion posts worked very well! I do wish people had been more eager to participate in discussion section unfortunately.
virtual office hours and the small discussion sections worked well

All modes of learning were helpful, however I think there should be a way to mark if a student has already watched the recorded lectures. As these are part of the attendance grade, they are important. I missed some points for participation simply because I wasnt sure which videos I had already watched.
Was very well geared to the COVID-19 pandemic
Small discussion groups were a successful and engaging practice.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! I actually enjoyed learning about ancient civilizations and archaeology, the latter a field I didn't know very much about.

I would not recommend this class to another student in the virtual format, but I would if it were in an in-person format. I think the virtual format detracted a lot from this course. The class was very good for getting a basis in understanding archaeology throughout the world, but it just wasn't that engaging the way it was taught online.
Yes! Solid social science credit, with clear ways to score excellently, and interesting content! Please appreciate the professor she is a great prof!
Yes. I learned a lot more knowledge that expanded upon concepts I had learned prior.
Yes, the professor and the material were both engaging.
Yes, it is quite interesting and gives you a great start for anthropology and archeology
Yes, especially in a post-pandemic time, when students can engage with the material hands on.
